about.title: About
about.subtitle: A bit about who I am and what I enjoy working on.
about.intro_p1: I'm a technology consultant who enjoys turning ambiguous problems into clear, user‚Äëcentered solutions. Over the past few years, I've worked across banking and retail, helping teams modernize their systems, improve customer experiences, and ship reliable products.
about.intro_p2: My work usually sits at the intersection of business analysis, product thinking, and engineering ‚Äî from mapping out future‚Äëstate architectures to building lightweight tools that automate away repetitive work.
about.what_i_do_desc: Bridge business needs and technical teams to design and deliver practical digital solutions.
about.what_i_care_desc: Build thoughtful systems and experiences that actually benefit the people using them.
about.hobby_climbing_desc: Finding new routes, solving movement puzzles, and enjoying time on the wall.
about.hobby_photo_desc: Taking photos of everyday scenes, friends, and trips to document life as it happens.
about.hobby_running_desc: Short city runs to reset, think through ideas, and stay active between projects.
about.hobby_building_desc: Experimenting with small tools and prototypes to try new tech and deploy ideas quickly.

post1.title: The AI Agent Hype vs. Reality: A Practitioner's Guide for 2026
post1.excerpt: Cut through the noise and understand what AI agents can actually deliver. Real examples of successes, failures, and a practical framework for evaluation.
post1.author: üë§ Gary Yong

content.intro1: Last week, I saw an ad claiming AI agents could "replace 20 employees overnight." On platforms like Moltbook‚Äîa social network where AI bots interact autonomously‚Äîpeople are posting about agents "starting religions" and developing their own thoughts. Meanwhile, my inbox is flooded with pitches for "revolutionary AI workforce solutions."
content.intro2: Sound familiar? Welcome to 2026's AI agent gold rush.
content.intro3: As someone who's spent years implementing AI solutions across enterprise environments, I've witnessed both spectacular successes and spectacular failures. Here's what I've learned about separating hype from reality.
content.section1_p1: Let's start with a success story. I recently worked with a major bank deploying Google's conversational AI for their contact center. The system combines voice bots with real-time speech analytics‚Äîand the results were impressive: 40% reduction in call resolution time and measurably improved customer satisfaction.
content.section1_p2: The key to their success? They didn't try to replace humans‚Äîthey augmented them.
content.section1_p3: The AI handles routine inquiries (balance checks, transaction history, basic troubleshooting) while seamlessly escalating complex issues to human agents with full context. Speech analytics identifies customer sentiment in real-time, helping agents adjust their approach mid-conversation.
content.section1_p4: This isn't flashy disruption. It's practical, measurable improvement that directly impacts both the bottom line and customer experience.
content.section2_p1: Not every implementation succeeds. I've observed a consistent pattern: systems work beautifully in controlled testing, then fall apart when they encounter the messy exceptions that define real business operations.
content.section2_p2: The failures typically stem from three root causes:
section2_bullets: Misaligned expectations: Organizations expect AI agents to handle every edge case and understand context like humans. When reality falls short of these expectations, disappointment follows.

Rigid AI in flexible environments: AI excels at consistency, but many business processes require flexibility and judgment. Forcing rigid automation onto inherently flexible processes creates frustration for everyone.

Poor data quality: This is the silent killer. Fragmented, inconsistent data doesn't just reduce accuracy‚Äîit can stall projects entirely. Clean, structured data isn't optional; it's the foundation everything else is built on.
content.section3_p1: Before greenlighting any AI agent project, I ask three questions:
section3_list: Is this genuinely repetitive? If there's significant variation or creativity required, human oversight remains essential.
How sensitive is the data? High-sensitivity environments need additional safeguards and human checkpoints. Security can't be an afterthought.
What does success look like‚Äîspecifically? Vague goals like "improve efficiency" aren't enough. You need measurable KPIs everyone agrees on before development begins.
content.section3_p2: These questions eliminate about 60% of problematic projects before they start.
content.section3_p3: For implementations already underway, I apply three litmus tests: consistency (same input, same output every time), graceful human handoff (seamless escalation when the AI hits its limits), and real-world performance (results outside controlled testing).
content.section4_p1: Despite the hype, real progress is happening. The developments I'm most excited about:
content.section4_p2: Proactive task management: Agents that anticipate needs rather than just responding to requests‚Äîscheduling meetings based on email context, flagging potential issues before they become problems, managing workflows across systems.
content.section4_p3: Persistent memory and learning: We're moving from reactive systems to assistants that remember context and adapt over time. The next 12-18 months will bring more powerful models with better tool integration and genuine learning capabilities.
content.section4_quote: The AI agent revolution is real‚Äîbut it's about augmenting human capabilities, not replacing humans wholesale.
content.section5_p1: If you're evaluating AI agents for your organization, here's my advice:
content.section5_p2: Start small. Target your most repetitive tasks with clear success metrics. Don't try to automate everything at once.
content.section5_p3: Invest in data quality. The organizations that will succeed are those building the infrastructure to support sophisticated AI systems. That starts with clean, structured data.
content.section5_p4: Design for humans. The best implementations enhance human capabilities rather than replacing them. Build in oversight, intervention points, and graceful fallbacks.
content.section5_p5: The companies that understand the distinction between hype and reality‚Äîand implement AI agents accordingly‚Äîwill thrive. Those chasing headlines without understanding fundamentals will waste time, money, and opportunity.
content.cta_question: What's your experience with AI agents?
content.cta_text: I'd love to hear your stories. Connect with me on LinkedIn to continue the conversation.

post2.title: Why Most AI Projects Fail (And How to Make Yours Succeed)
post2.excerpt: Drawing from enterprise consulting experience, learn the real reasons AI projects fail and get a practical evaluation framework.
post2.author: Gary Yong

content.intro_p1: The AI hype is real, but so is the failure rate. After implementing AI solutions for clients across finance, healthcare, and retail at Capco, I've seen the same pattern repeat: organizations rush to adopt AI, invest heavily in technology, and then watch their projects fizzle out after a few months.
content.intro_p2: The statistics are sobering. Industry reports suggest that 85% of AI projects fail to deliver meaningful business value. But here's the thing‚Äîit's rarely about the technology itself. The failures happen long before you choose between TensorFlow and PyTorch.
content.section1_title: The Real Culprits Behind AI Project Failures
content.subsection1_p1: I can't count how many discovery calls start with "We want to implement AI" rather than "We have this business problem." Last year, I worked with a mid-sized insurance company whose executive team was convinced they needed an AI chatbot. Three weeks of process analysis revealed their real issue: customer service reps were spending 60% of their time manually looking up policy information in legacy systems.
content.subsection1_p2: The solution wasn't AI‚Äîit was better data integration. We built a simple dashboard that aggregated customer data from three systems into one view. Customer response time improved by 40%, and the project cost 80% less than the proposed chatbot.
content.subsection2_title: 2. Ignoring the People Side of Change
content.subsection2_p1: Technology is the easy part. People are complex. In my experience, the most sophisticated AI system will fail if your team isn't prepared for how it changes their daily work.
content.subsection2_p2: At a healthcare client, we built an AI tool that could flag potential diagnosis errors in medical records. The technology worked brilliantly in testing‚Äî95% accuracy, lightning-fast processing. But six months post-launch, adoption was stuck at 12%. Why? The doctors felt the system was questioning their expertise rather than supporting it.
content.subsection2_p3: We redesigned the interface to position AI suggestions as "additional considerations" rather than "error alerts." Adoption jumped to 78% within two months. Same technology, different framing.
content.subsection3_p1: Here's a harsh truth: AI amplifies the quality of your data‚Äîboth good and bad. Garbage in, garbage out, but faster and at scale.
content.subsection3_p2: I worked with a retail client who wanted to implement demand forecasting AI. Their historical sales data was a mess‚Äîdifferent product SKUs, inconsistent naming conventions, missing seasonal data. They wanted to launch in 12 weeks. We spent 16 weeks just cleaning and standardizing their data before we could even start training models.
content.section2_title: The Gary Yong Framework for AI Readiness
content.section2_intro: After implementing dozens of AI projects, I've developed a framework that helps organizations honestly assess their readiness. I call it the PRIME framework:
content.prime_p_desc: Before automating anything, you need to understand your current processes deeply. Can your team clearly articulate the steps involved in the work AI will assist with? Are these processes documented and standardized?
content.prime_p_flag: Red flag: If different people do the same job differently, AI will struggle to provide consistent value.
content.prime_r_desc: AI isn't a one-time purchase‚Äîit's an ongoing investment. Do you have dedicated budget for data infrastructure, model maintenance, and team training? Are key stakeholders prepared to spend 20-30% of their time on the project for the first six months?
content.prime_r_flag: Red flag: If AI is being funded from "leftover" budget or treated as a side project, it will fail.
content.prime_i_desc: How will AI fit into your existing technology stack? What systems need to talk to each other? Who owns the integration process?
content.prime_i_flag: Red flag: If your IT team learns about the AI project in the implementation phase, you're in trouble.
content.prime_m_desc: What specific metrics will prove success? How will you track them? What's your baseline performance?
content.prime_m_flag: Red flag: If success is defined as "improved efficiency" without specific numbers, you can't prove ROI.
content.prime_e_desc: AI isn't magic. It won't replace human judgment, solve all your problems, or deliver results overnight. Are stakeholders' expectations realistic?
content.prime_e_flag: Red flag: If anyone uses the phrase "AI will solve everything," run the other direction.
content.section3_p1: Let me share a project that got it right. A financial services client approached me with a specific problem: their loan underwriters were spending 3-4 hours per application manually reviewing financial documents and cross-referencing data points.
content.section3_p2: We scored high on all PRIME dimensions: clear processes (documented underwriting guidelines), committed resources (dedicated budget and team), solid integration plan (API access to core systems), specific metrics (reduce review time to under 1 hour while maintaining approval accuracy), and realistic expectations (AI assists, humans decide).
content.section3_p3: The result? We built an AI system that pre-populates application reviews with key data points and flags potential issues. Average review time dropped to 45 minutes, approval accuracy improved by 12%, and the underwriters love it because it eliminates tedious data entry and lets them focus on complex decision-making.
content.section4_intro: If you're considering an AI project, start with these questions:
content.section4_q1: What specific business problem are we solving? If you can't answer this in one sentence, stop and clarify first.
content.section4_q2: How do we currently handle this process? Document everything, measure everything.
content.section4_q3: Who will be affected by this change? Talk to them early and often.
content.section4_q4: What data do we need, and what's its current quality? Be brutal in your assessment.
content.section4_q5: How will we measure success? Set specific, measurable goals.
content.section4_conclusion: AI can deliver transformational results‚Äîbut only when implemented thoughtfully, strategically, and with deep respect for the human elements of change. The technology has never been more capable. The question is: are you ready for it?
content.cta: Want to explore whether AI is right for your organization? I help companies navigate this exact journey. Let's talk about your specific challenges and build a roadmap that actually delivers results.

post3.title: From Consulting to AI Side Project: What I'm Learning
post3.excerpt: Insights from transitioning between consulting and entrepreneurship, and how both experiences shaped my approach to technology projects.
post3.author: Gary Yong

content.intro_p1: I'm currently an Implementation Consultant at Capco, working with major banks and financial institutions on complex transformation projects. It's challenging work that I genuinely enjoy. But over the past year, I've been exploring something on the side: YongAI, an AI consulting initiative that applies everything I've learned in enterprise consulting to helping organizations actually adopt AI.
content.intro_p2: I haven't quit my day job. I'm not writing this from a garage somewhere, burning through savings. This is about what happens when a consultant starts thinking like a builder ‚Äî and the surprising lessons that come from straddling both worlds.
content.section1_title: The Mindset Shift: From Optimization to Creation
content.section1_p1: In my consulting work, I'm a problem-solver. Clients come with established businesses, existing processes, and clear (if complex) challenges. My job is to diagnose issues, design solutions, and optimize what already exists. I've gotten good at this ‚Äî give me an underperforming process and I can map inefficiencies, propose improvements, and deliver measurable results.
content.section1_p2: Building something from scratch is a completely different muscle. With YongAI, there are no existing processes to optimize because nothing exists yet. Every framework, every offering, every potential client relationship has to be created from zero. This shift from "fixing what's broken" to "building what doesn't exist" requires a different kind of thinking.
content.section1_quote: In consulting, the hardest question is usually "How do we fix this?" When you're building something new, it's "What should I build?" ‚Äî and that question has infinite possible answers.
content.section2_title: Why Consultants Are Well-Positioned for This
content.section2_intro: The more I explore the AI space, the more I realize that consulting provides excellent preparation ‚Äî but not for the reasons you might expect.
content.subsection1_p1: Consultants thrive in unclear situations. Clients rarely come to us saying "Here's exactly what's wrong and exactly how to fix it." They say things like "Our sales are down, our employees seem unhappy, and we're losing market share." We're trained to work backwards from vague problems to specific, actionable solutions.
content.subsection1_p2: This skill translates directly to the AI space, where organizations know they "need AI" but have no idea where to start. When someone says "We think we need AI but we're not sure what kind," I don't panic ‚Äî I grab my trusty framework and start asking clarifying questions. That's just Tuesday for a consultant.
content.subsection2_title: We Know How to Build Trust Quickly
content.subsection2_p1: Consultants are professional outsiders. We walk into organizations where we know nobody, understand little about the industry specifics, and somehow need to gain enough trust that executives will listen to our recommendations on massive changes.
content.subsection2_p2: This ability to build credibility quickly is incredibly relevant when talking to organizations about AI. There's a lot of hype and a lot of skepticism. Being able to position yourself as someone who understands both the technology and the business reality ‚Äî that's a consulting superpower.
content.subsection3_p1: Good consultants know that initial hypotheses are usually wrong. You start with educated guesses, test them against reality, and pivot when the data says you're off track. This "strong opinions, weakly held" mindset is essential when exploring new territory.
content.subsection3_p2: My original thinking for YongAI focused heavily on building custom AI solutions. But the more conversations I had, the more I realized most organizations don't need custom models ‚Äî they need help integrating existing AI tools into their workflows and building the organizational capability to use them. That realization reshaped my entire approach.
content.section3_title: The Traps I'm Watching Out For
content.section3_intro: Not everything from consulting translates well. Here are the tendencies I've noticed in myself that I'm actively trying to counteract:
content.trap1_p1: Consultants are trained to deliver polished, comprehensive solutions. We create detailed frameworks, beautiful presentations, and thorough documentation. When you're exploring a new venture, this perfectionism can be paralyzing.
content.trap1_p2: I caught myself spending weeks building elaborate positioning documents before I'd even validated the core idea with real people. Those documents were thorough, well-researched, and premature. Conversations with actual prospects taught me more about what the market needs than any amount of desk research.
content.trap2_p1: When faced with uncertainty, consultants gather more data. We run surveys, conduct interviews, and build models until we feel confident. When you're exploring something new, this can become a comfortable hiding place ‚Äî an excuse to keep researching instead of actually doing.
content.trap2_p2: I've had to push myself to move from analysis to action faster than feels natural. Sometimes the answer comes from a 15-minute conversation, not a six-week research project.
content.trap3_p1: Consulting projects have defined timelines, clear success metrics, and built-in ending points. When a project goes sideways, there's usually shared accountability. Building your own thing is emotionally different ‚Äî every win and every setback feels personal in a way that client work doesn't.
content.trap3_p2: Learning to treat feedback as market data rather than personal rejection has been an ongoing calibration.
content.section4_title: What I'm Taking Away So Far
content.section4_takeaway1: Start conversations before you're ready. Consultants are used to feeling fully prepared before presenting to clients. When exploring a new direction, "ready enough" beats "perfect." I should have started talking to people about this idea months earlier than I did.
content.section4_takeaway2: Your network is your unfair advantage. Those years of building relationships with executives, understanding their challenges, and proving your competence? That's not just a career asset ‚Äî it's a launchpad. The trust you've already built opens doors that cold outreach never could.
content.section4_takeaway3: The gap in the market is real. Through my consulting work, I've seen firsthand how many organizations struggle with AI adoption ‚Äî not because the technology isn't there, but because they lack the structured approach to evaluate, implement, and scale it. That's a consulting problem, not a tech problem. And consultants are uniquely equipped to solve it.
content.section5_p1: I don't have a dramatic "I quit my job" story. What I have is a growing conviction that the intersection of enterprise consulting and AI implementation is where I can create the most value. My experience at Capco ‚Äî running workshops, mapping processes, managing complex stakeholder environments ‚Äî is directly applicable to helping organizations navigate AI adoption.
content.section5_p2: YongAI is still early. I'm learning, experimenting, and figuring out what the right offering looks like. But the foundation is solid: deep consulting methodology applied to the most transformative technology of our generation.
content.section5_p3: For other consultants who see the same opportunity ‚Äî you don't have to make a dramatic leap. Start exploring. Have conversations. Build something small on the side. The skills you've developed solving complex business problems are exactly what the AI space needs right now.
content.section5_conclusion: The best part? All those years of helping other people build better businesses are preparing you to build something meaningful of your own.

post4.title: The Enterprise AI Playbook: 5 Steps I Use With Every Client
post4.excerpt: A proven methodology for evaluating, planning, and implementing AI solutions in enterprise environments, with real case studies.
post4.author: Gary Yong

content.intro_p1: After implementing AI solutions across finance, healthcare, retail, and manufacturing, I've learned that successful AI projects follow a predictable pattern. The technology varies, the business contexts differ, but the methodology remains consistent.
content.intro_p2: This is the exact 5-step framework I use with every client‚Äîrefined through dozens of engagements, countless failures, and the hard-earned wisdom that comes from turning AI experiments into business value. It works because it prioritizes business outcomes over technical sophistication.
content.intro_quote: The goal isn't to implement the most advanced AI possible. It's to implement AI that delivers measurable business value within realistic constraints.
content.step1_title: Step 1: Process Audit ‚Äî Understanding What Actually Happens
content.step1_p1: Before we talk about AI, we talk about work. I spend the first week of every engagement shadowing employees, mapping workflows, and understanding the gap between "how we're supposed to do things" and "how things actually get done."

step1_bullets.1: Decision points where humans apply consistent criteria
step1_bullets.2: Information bottlenecks where data flows slowly between systems
step1_bullets.3: Quality control steps that could benefit from automated checking

content.step1_example_title: Real Example: Regional Bank Loan Processing
content.step1_example_p1: A regional bank wanted to "use AI for loan approvals." After the process audit, I discovered their real problem wasn't approval decisions‚Äîit was that loan officers spent 3-4 hours per application manually gathering customer financial data from multiple systems and documents.
content.step1_example_p2: The AI opportunity wasn't in making approval decisions (that required human judgment) but in automating data collection and validation. We built an AI system that extracts financial data from documents and cross-references it with internal systems, reducing manual work from 4 hours to 30 minutes per application.
content.step1_result: Result: 87% reduction in processing time, 40% increase in loan officer productivity, zero change to approval workflows.
content.step2_title: Step 2: Opportunity Scoring ‚Äî The ROI Reality Check
content.step2_p1: Not every AI opportunity is worth pursuing. I use a scoring framework that evaluates potential projects across four dimensions:

step2_data_bullets.0: Is the necessary data already being collected?
step2_data_bullets.2: How accessible is it for AI training?

step2_impact_bullets.0: How much time/cost could automation save?
step2_impact_bullets.1: Would improvements unlock new revenue opportunities?
step2_impact_bullets.2: Are there quality improvements beyond efficiency?

step2_validation_bullets.0: How easily can we measure success?
step2_validation_bullets.1: Are the business rules clear and consistent?
step2_validation_bullets.2: Can we start with a limited pilot?

content.step2_example_p1: A manufacturer wanted AI-powered visual inspection of products. Here's how it scored:

step2_example_bullets.1: Impact: 23/25 (could reduce inspection time by 70%, catch defects humans miss)
step2_example_bullets.2: Validation: 22/25 (clear success metrics, easy to compare AI vs human results)
step2_example_bullets.3: Execution: 18/25 (some resistance from quality team, integration challenges)

content.step2_conclusion: This systematic scoring prevents the common mistake of pursuing technically interesting projects that don't deliver business value.
content.step3_title: Step 3: Pilot Selection ‚Äî Starting Small, Thinking Big
content.step3_p1: The highest-scoring opportunity isn't always the best pilot. I select pilots based on three criteria:

step3_goldilocks_bullets.0: Not too simple: Won't demonstrate AI's true potential
step3_goldilocks_bullets.1: Not too complex: Too many variables for initial implementation
step3_goldilocks_bullets.2: Just right: Meaningful business impact with manageable scope

content.step3_example_p1: A healthcare system had three AI opportunities: automated diagnosis support (too complex for pilot), appointment scheduling optimization (too simple), and clinical notes summarization (just right).
content.step3_example_p2: The pilot focused on summarizing patient encounter notes for specialist referrals. It was contained (only referral docs), measurable (time savings, referral quality), and valuable (specialists spent 30% less time reading background information).
content.step3_result: Pilot results: 45% reduction in referral review time, 23% improvement in referral accuracy, 92% physician satisfaction score.
content.step3_conclusion: Success with the pilot gave us credibility and budget for the more ambitious diagnosis support system.
content.step4_title: Step 4: Build & Test ‚Äî The MVP Mindset
content.step4_p1: Enterprise AI projects fail when they try to solve everything at once. I build AI solutions like software products: minimum viable product first, then iterate based on real usage.

step4_philosophy_bullets.0: Start with existing tools: ChatGPT API, Claude, established ML services
step4_philosophy_bullets.1: Custom only when necessary: Most problems don't need custom models
step4_philosophy_bullets.2: Human-in-the-loop always: AI suggests, humans decide (at least initially)
step4_philosophy_bullets.3: Measure everything: Usage patterns, accuracy rates, user satisfaction

content.step4_example_p1: An insurance company wanted AI to automatically approve/deny claims. Instead of building a full automation system, we started with an AI assistant that flagged unusual claims and suggested next steps.
content.step4_example_phase1: Phase 1 MVP: AI reads claim documents, extracts key information, flags potential issues. Claims adjusters still make all decisions but with better information faster.
content.step4_conclusion: The success of Phase 1 built trust for Phase 2: automated approval of simple, low-risk claims. We're now processing 40% of claims with minimal human intervention.
content.step5_title: Step 5: Scale & Monitor ‚Äî From Pilot to Platform
content.step5_p1: Scaling AI requires shifting from project thinking to product thinking. You're not just expanding a successful pilot‚Äîyou're building an AI capability that will evolve and improve over time.

step5_technical_bullets.0: API endpoints that can handle production load
step5_technical_bullets.1: Data pipelines for retraining and updates

step5_organizational_bullets.0: Training programs for expanded user base
step5_organizational_bullets.1: Updated job descriptions and performance metrics

content.step5_example_p1: A retail chain piloted AI-powered inventory forecasting in 5 stores. After proving a 20% reduction in stockouts and 15% decrease in overstock, we scaled to 150 stores.

step5_challenges.0: Data quality: Built automated data validation for different store formats
step5_challenges.1: Change management: Trained 150+ store managers on new forecasting process
step5_challenges.2: Performance monitoring: Dashboard tracking forecast accuracy by store, region, and product category
step5_challenges.3: Continuous improvement: Monthly model retraining with new sales data

content.patterns_p1: While every client is unique, I see consistent patterns in what makes AI projects successful:

winners_bullets.0: Augmentation over automation: AI helping humans work better, not replacing them
winners_bullets.1: Process improvement: Using AI to eliminate bottlenecks and inefficiencies
winners_bullets.2: Data quality: Investing in clean, consistent, accessible data
winners_bullets.3: Change management: Preparing people for new workflows

failures_bullets.0: Skipping the process audit (building solutions for assumed problems)
failures_bullets.1: Pursuing technically impressive but business-irrelevant projects
failures_bullets.3: Ignoring user adoption and change management

content.roadmap_p1: If you're ready to implement AI in your organization, start with these questions:

roadmap_questions.0: What processes consume the most time/resources? (Step 1 prep)
roadmap_questions.1: Where do we have good data already? (Step 2 foundation)
roadmap_questions.2: What's a contained problem we could solve in 8-12 weeks? (Step 3 pilot)
roadmap_questions.3: Who are our AI champions and skeptics? (Step 4 change management)

content.roadmap_p2: This framework has guided successful AI implementations worth millions in business value. It works because it respects both the power of AI and the complexity of organizational change.
content.roadmap_remember: Remember: The goal isn't to deploy the most sophisticated AI possible. It's to deploy AI that solves real problems, delivers measurable value, and sets the foundation for your organization's AI-powered future.
content.cta: Ready to implement AI in your organization? I've guided dozens of companies through this exact framework. Let's discuss how it applies to your specific challenges and opportunities.

post5.title: I Built an AI Clone of Myself ‚Äî Here's What Happened
post5.excerpt: Creating Ask Gary was supposed to be a fun portfolio piece. Instead, it became a fascinating experiment in conversational AI and user psychology.
post5.author: Gary Yong

content.intro_p1: What started as a weekend coding project to add some personality to my portfolio has turned into one of the most educational AI experiments I've ever conducted. "Ask Gary" was supposed to be a simple chatbot that could answer basic questions about my background. Six months and 2,000+ conversations later, it's taught me more about human-AI interaction than any industry report ever could.
content.intro_p2: Here's the story of building an AI version of myself, the technical decisions that shaped it, and the fascinating insights from watching people interact with my digital twin.
content.brief_p1: The concept was straightforward: create an AI assistant that could handle the basic questions I get asked repeatedly‚Äîmy background, experience, project details, and availability. Think of it as an interactive FAQ that could engage in natural conversation.

brief_bullets.1: Accurate: Only provide information I'd actually share
brief_bullets.2: Progressive: Get smarter over time based on interactions
brief_bullets.3: Authentic: Sound like me, not a generic chatbot

content.brief_p3: Little did I know that last requirement would be the most challenging and interesting part of the entire project.
content.architecture_title: Technical Architecture: Keeping It Simple (But Scalable)
content.stack_p1: I built Ask Gary using a surprisingly minimal tech stack:

stack_bullets.0: Frontend: Vanilla JavaScript with a custom widget
stack_bullets.2: AI Engine: OpenAI's GPT-4 with custom prompts
stack_bullets.4: Hosting: AWS EC2 with PM2 for process management

content.stack_p2: The beauty of this setup is its simplicity. No complex vector databases, no fine-tuned models, no microservices architecture. Just clean, maintainable code that does exactly what it needs to do.
content.personality_p1: The hardest part wasn't the technical implementation‚Äîit was teaching an AI to sound like me. How do you distill your communication style, humor, and personality quirks into prompt engineering?
content.personality_p2: I started by analyzing my own writing patterns. I read through hundreds of my emails, Slack messages, and LinkedIn posts, looking for consistent patterns:

personality_bullets.0: I tend to use specific examples rather than generic statements
personality_bullets.1: I'm direct but friendly, professional but not stiff
personality_bullets.2: I often use analogies to explain technical concepts
personality_bullets.3: I ask clarifying questions rather than making assumptions

content.personality_p3: These insights became the foundation of Ask Gary's system prompt, which I refined over dozens of iterations based on how natural the conversations felt.
content.engagement_p1: Here's where Ask Gary gets interesting. Instead of treating every interaction as isolated, it builds context over the course of a conversation. The system tracks:

engagement_bullets.0: What information the user has already received
engagement_bullets.1: The level of technical detail they seem comfortable with
engagement_bullets.2: Whether they're asking personal, professional, or technical questions
engagement_bullets.3: How engaged they are (based on follow-up questions)

content.engagement_p2: This allows Ask Gary to provide increasingly personalized responses. If someone asks about my AI experience and then follows up with technical questions, the system recognizes they want deeper detail. If they ask personal questions, it shifts to a more casual tone.
content.patterns_title: What People Actually Ask (And What Surprised Me)
content.patterns_p1: After thousands of conversations, I've learned that people interact with AI differently than I expected. Here are the most fascinating patterns:
content.testing_p1: Almost everyone starts by testing the AI's knowledge boundaries. Common first questions:

testing_bullets.0: "What's Gary's favorite color?" (Answer: I don't have one, but I like colors that work well in data visualizations)
testing_bullets.1: "Where did Gary go to school?" (McMaster University)
testing_bullets.2: "What's Gary's biggest weakness?" (I over-engineer solutions sometimes)

content.testing_p2: People want to understand what the AI knows and how accurately it represents me before asking more meaningful questions.
content.coaching_p1: This was completely unexpected. About 30% of conversations turn into career advice discussions. People ask:

coaching_bullets.1: "Should I specialize in AI or stay generalist?"
coaching_bullets.2: "What's the best way to transition from X to Y?"

content.coaching_p2: Ask Gary has become an impromptu career counselor, drawing on my experiences to provide personalized advice. These are often the longest, most engaged conversations.
content.technical_p1: Engineers love to get technical. They ask about architecture decisions, trade-offs in AI implementations, and specific methodologies. These conversations often last 20+ messages as people probe deeper into technical details.
content.technical_p2: What's interesting is how the AI adapts its explanations based on the user's background. When someone asks about machine learning model selection, Ask Gary gauges their expertise level and adjusts accordingly.
content.uncanny_p1: One unexpected challenge has been managing user expectations about what Ask Gary can and cannot do. Some people forget they're talking to an AI and ask questions that require real-time information or personal opinions I haven't programmed in.
content.uncanny_p2: The solution was to make the AI's limitations transparent and even leverage them as conversation starters. When Ask Gary doesn't know something, it says so honestly and suggests how the user could get the real answer (often by contacting me directly).
content.uncanny_quote: "I don't have access to Gary's calendar, but I can tell you he's usually most responsive to LinkedIn messages for scheduling discussions about AI consulting projects."
content.business_p1: What started as a portfolio piece has turned into a legitimate business tool. Ask Gary has:

business_bullets.0: Qualified leads: Many conversations end with "How do I hire Gary for a project?"
business_bullets.1: Built relationships: People feel like they know me before we ever speak
business_bullets.2: Saved time: I no longer answer the same basic questions repeatedly
business_bullets.3: Provided insights: I understand what people want to know about my work

content.business_p2: Three client relationships started with Ask Gary conversations. People appreciated the ability to learn about my approach and experience before committing to a sales call.
content.lessons_title: Lessons Learned (And What I'd Do Differently)
content.version2_p1: If I were rebuilding Ask Gary today, I'd add:

version2_bullets.0: Voice interface: Many people want to talk rather than type
version2_bullets.2: Visual responses: Show relevant work samples or diagrams

content.human_p1: As sophisticated as Ask Gary has become, the most meaningful conversations still happen when people connect with me directly. The AI is excellent at providing information and initial engagement, but it can't replace human connection for complex discussions.
content.human_p2: Ask Gary works best as a bridge‚Äîintroducing people to my work and approach, then seamlessly transitioning to human interaction when appropriate.
content.psychology_title: The Psychology of Talking to Yourself
content.psychology_p1: Here's something I didn't anticipate: interacting with an AI version of myself has been surprisingly reflective. Reading conversations helps me understand how others perceive my communication style and what aspects of my work resonate most with people.
content.psychology_p2: It's also shown me patterns in my own thinking that I wasn't aware of. Ask Gary consistently structures responses in ways that mirror how I approach complex problems‚Äîbreaking them down, providing context, offering practical next steps. Seeing this pattern externalized has made me more intentional about how I communicate.
content.future_p1: The experiment continues. I'm exploring ways to make Ask Gary even more useful while maintaining the authentic, personal feel that makes it engaging. The goal isn't to replace human interaction but to enhance it‚Äîproviding better context for meaningful conversations.
content.future_p2: If you haven't tried Ask Gary yet, I encourage you to give it a conversation. Ask it anything you're curious about regarding AI, consulting, or career transitions. You might be surprised by how natural it feels to talk to an AI version of someone you've never met.
content.future_p3: And if you're building your own AI assistant, remember that the technology is just the beginning. The real challenge‚Äîand the real opportunity‚Äîis in capturing the human nuances that make conversations genuinely helpful and engaging.

contact.title: Contact
contact.subtitle: Let's discuss how we can work together.

ask_gary.title: Ask Gary
ask_gary.subtitle: Personal AI Career Agent
ask_gary.welcome_p1: Hi! I'm Ask Gary, Gary's career assistant. I'm here to answer questions about his professional background, skills, projects, and experiences on his behalf.
ask_gary.welcome_p2: Feel free to ask me anything‚Äîfor example: "What did Gary do at Capco?" or "Tell me about Gary's experience with AI and automation."
ask_gary.input_placeholder: Ask something about Gary's experience, skills, or projects‚Ä¶
ask_gary.question_2: "Summarize Gary's experience with AI and automation."
ask_gary.question_4: "Tell me about Gary's technical skills and programming languages."
ask_gary.question_5: "What kind of consulting projects has Gary worked on?"
ask_gary.how_1: Answers are grounded only in Gary's resumes and career docs.
ask_gary.how_2: Top‚ÄëK relevant chunks are retrieved for each question.
ask_gary.how_3: The model is instructed to say "I don't know" when context is missing.
ask_gary.hint: This page is backed by a FastAPI service and a retrieval‚Äëaugmented generation pipeline using OpenAI embeddings and a lightweight in‚Äëmemory index.
